Title: The Session
DescriptionLines: **The Session**, which is derived from the Document Store, is the primary way your client code interacts with your RavenDB databases.
The Session is a unit of work that represents a single business transaction against a particular database,
managing change tracking for all the entities that it has either loaded or stored.

Walkthroughs.Title: Open the Session
DescriptionLines: * Direct communication with the database is done through the `Session`.
Start by obtaining a new Session object from the Document Store.
* Any change made to the documents loaded to the Session will be _tracked_ by the Session.
These changes will be persisted to the database when calling saveChanges() later on.
* _Note_:
* If no database is specified then the _default_ database (stored in the Document Store) is used.

Walkthroughs.Title: Work on your documents
DescriptionLines: * Using the Session, perform needed operations on your documents.
e.g. store a new document, modify an existing document, query your database, etc.
* Any such operation _'loads'_ these documents entities to the Session for tracking.
You donâ€™t need to manually track the changes to these 'loaded' document entities and decide what needs to be saved and what doesn't.
The Session will do it for you.
* The Session tracks both the documents body and metadata - any change made will be sent back to the server when saveChanges() is called later on.
* A configurable _number of requests_ can be made within a single session to the server.
Design your code - use multiple Sessions as needed.

Walkthroughs.Title: Save the changes
DescriptionLines: * The `saveChanges()` call checks the Session state for _all_ changes made (e.g. a new entity was added) -
you don't need to call saveChanges() per changed entity.
* These changes are sent to the server as a single remote call that will complete transactionally.
In other words, either all changes are saved as a single unit or none of them are.
* Once saveChanges() returns, it is guaranteed that the changes are persisted to the database.
* The saveChanges() is the only time when a RavenDB client sends updates to the server,
so that you will experience a reduced number of network calls.

Walkthroughs.Title: Close the session
DescriptionLines: * Call `close()` to dispose the session object when done.
